subject: Re: [junit] Problems using command line parameters in test cases
msgSnippet: I would suggest using JVM system properties instead. That was how I configured my test cases to know in which part of the file system to look for test files.
messageBody:
I would suggest using JVM system properties instead. That was how I
configured my test cases to know in which part of the file system to look
for test files.

In my top-most test fixture class I have:

public abstract class JBRTestFixture extends TestCase {
...
protected File getUnitTestFolder() { return new File(System.getProperty
("test.root", "/unitTest/data")); }
}

In my test case I have:

public class MyTestCase extends JBRTestFixture {
....
protected File getDataFile() { return new File(getUnitTestFolder(),
"/mySubFolder/myFile.dat"); }
...
public void testReadFromDataFile() {
...
assertEquals(expectedContents, readContents(getDataFile()));
}
...
}

When I run the TestRunner, I simply define the system property "test.root"
appropriately. The default value is "/unitTest/data" on the current volume.

Good luck.

Subject: [junit] Problems using command line parameters in test cases



Can somebody help explain how to use command line parameters in test
cases. I have the following main method in my test case.

public static void main(String[] args) {
propFile = args[0];
String[] name = {PCAModelTest.class.getName()};
TestRunner.main(name);
}

I try to pass the name of the property file to use to configure the test
fixture as a command line parameter. The propFile variable is a static
defined in the test case. When I enter the setUp method of my test case,
propFile is null. I don't know what's going on here. Can somebody help
explain it to me and possibly tell me how I can achieve my desired
result of using command line parameters in my setUp method?

Grant
